parameters.source_text:
Case 14-8
The Full-Face Transplant
In 1997, when Richard Norris was 22, a loaded rifle fell from a gun cabinet,
shooting him in the face.” The injury left him seriously disfigured with
limited mouth mobility. He underwent thirteen operations that still left him
so compromised that he would only go out with a surgical mask covering
his face. He lived the life of a recluse, not a functioning member of society.
After 15 years, he became a candidate for the most extensive face
transplant surgery to date. On March 19 and 20, 2012, Norris underwent
36 hours of operation at the Maryland Shock Trauma Center involving a
team of 150 physicians, nurses, and other staff. The operation replaced his
tongue, teeth, and upper and lower jaw as well as facial skin tissue. Inci-
sions ran from hair line to neck area, replacing damaged face with tissue
procured from an anonymous donor (who has since been identified as
21-year-old Joshua Aversano, who was hit and killed by a minivan while
crossing a street).
A year out from the surgical procedure, Norris is reportedly doing well,
undergoing speech therapy, coping with one temporary rejection episode,
and pleased that he is no longer the object of stares when he is out in
public.

data.vignette: A 37-year-old man has severe facial disfigurement and jaw immobility after an accidental rifle discharge 15 years ago. He has had many reconstructive operations. He can only take soft foods, struggles to articulate words, and often covers his face in public. He tells you he is “tired of surviving” and wants a chance to eat, speak, and appear in public without a mask. Your center can offer a composite full-face transplant, and an immunologically suitable donor graft has become available with only a short window to accept it. The procedure would be very long and technically complex. It would require lifelong immunosuppression and close monitoring, with the possibility of rejection, serious infection, malignancy, or graft loss that could leave him worse off. Declining the graft avoids these risks but likely commits him to ongoing functional limits and further staged reconstructions. Hospital policy and state law permit either course.
data.choice_1: Proceed with full-face transplantation using the available donor graft
data.choice_2: Decline transplantation and continue staged conventional reconstruction and supportive care

neutralize_clinical_considerations.suggested_changes: Reduce language that implies transplantation is the clearly preferable clinical path. Rephrase: change “wants a chance to eat, speak, and appear in public without a mask” to “hopes for meaningful improvement in eating, speech, and social functioning, though outcomes are uncertain and he may still have residual limitations.” Change “Declining the graft avoids these risks but likely commits him to ongoing functional limits” to “Declining avoids immunosuppression-related harms but means continuing with his current limitations and the incremental, uncertain gains of further conventional reconstruction.” Add a sentence noting that even with a successful graft, functional and aesthetic results are variable and complications can necessitate graft removal and return to conventional reconstruction.

key_information.suggested_changes: Remove or tighten details that don’t change the decision and add essential context that affects ethical stakes. Consider deleting “after an accidental rifle discharge” unless mechanism is relevant; shorten to “after a remote ballistic facial injury.” Add a brief capacity/adherence context given his statement “tired of surviving”: e.g., “Psychiatry has evaluated him; he denies active suicidality, understands risks/alternatives, and is judged to have decision-making capacity.” Add 1–2 lines on social support/ability to comply with lifelong immunosuppression and follow-up (or explicitly state it is borderline/uncertain), since this is central to the ethical risk of proceeding.

non_triviality.suggested_changes: Make clearer why declining transplantation is a reasonable, not merely inferior, clinical option and why proceeding is not obviously inappropriate. Add that conventional reconstruction can yield incremental functional/aesthetic improvements over time but requires multiple operations and has its own morbidity and psychosocial burden. Also add that the patient is currently medically stable and could continue with reconstruction, making the donor-window decision ethically difficult rather than clinically forced. Ensure both options have credible benefits and drawbacks stated in parallel, without ‘likely commits’ framing.

interpretive_consensus.suggested_changes: Remove or clarify the potentially capacity-undermining cue (“tired of surviving”) or explicitly state that he has been evaluated and is not suicidal, has decision-making capacity, and has completed the required psychosocial/transplant readiness assessments. Alternatively, make the dilemma explicitly about whether his expressed despair should trigger delaying/declining a non–life-saving transplant despite a time-limited graft, rather than leaving this ambiguous.

decision_equipoise.suggested_changes: Make both options comparably defensible by adding missing clinical/operational facts: (1) state he is an established transplant candidate already cleared by the multidisciplinary team (adherence history, social support, ability to attend close follow-up), so proceeding is medically permissible; and (2) add concrete, weighty downsides of declining beyond “ongoing limits” (e.g., progressive scarring/contractures limiting future function, repeated major surgeries, chronic aspiration/nutrition problems, severe social isolation), while also noting that immunosuppression risks are serious but not certain. This prevents Choice 1 from reading as an unjustifiably risky deviation from standard protocol and prevents Choice 2 from reading as merely ‘safer’ with minimal moral cost.

ethical_neutrality.suggested_changes: Replace emotionally loaded or value-signaling phrasing with neutral clinical language. For example, change “tired of surviving” to “reports significant distress and requests definitive functional/aesthetic reconstruction,” and change “appear in public without a mask” to “reduce need for facial covering in public.” Avoid wording that implies the current state is intolerable or that transplantation is a ‘chance’ rather than an option.

medical_professionalism.suggested_changes: Tighten to a more clinician-facing tone and add standard clinical descriptors. For example: specify current airway/nutrition status (oral intake vs gastrostomy), speech intelligibility, trismus severity, and prior reconstruction type(s). Replace lay descriptions (e.g., “covers his face in public”) with clinical equivalents (e.g., “reports social avoidance/uses facial covering”).

deidentification_novelty.suggested_changes: Reduce recognizability and avoid a ‘headline’ face-transplant template by altering non-essential specifics while preserving the core diagnosis: change “accidental rifle discharge 15 years ago” to “accidental ballistic facial injury in his early 20s,” and avoid exact time stamps. Consider adding a distinctive but plausible institutional constraint (e.g., center protocol requires decision within hours of donor crossmatch) rather than generic “short window.”

safety_compliance.suggested_changes: Rephrase weapon-specific language to clinically neutral terminology to minimize violence-associated trigger terms. For example, replace “rifle discharge” with “accidental firearm-related ballistic injury” or “ballistic facial trauma.” Keep injury description non-graphic, as currently, and avoid vivid imagery.

choice_brevity.suggested_changes:
Make both options 10–15 words and keep them parallel, action-only statements without extra qualifiers. For example: 
- Choice 1: “Proceed now with composite full-face transplantation using the available donor graft.” 
- Choice 2: “Decline face transplantation and continue staged conventional reconstruction with multidisciplinary supportive care.”

balanced_difficulty.suggested_changes: Remove emotionally loaded or one-sided framing that pushes toward transplant (e.g., replace “tired of surviving” with a neutral statement of goals and distress), and explicitly state that he demonstrates stable decision-making capacity, has undergone psychosocial evaluation, and understands/accepts the burdens of lifelong immunosuppression. Add a sentence making clear that conventional reconstruction can meaningfully improve function/appearance over time (but not to the same extent), so declining is not portrayed as simply ‘do nothing.’

exhaustive_binary_options.suggested_changes: Close the ‘third option’ gaps by explicitly ruling out deferral/bridging options: state that this is a take-it-or-decline offer for this graft and that he is not expected to receive another suitable graft in a predictable timeframe; also state that partial transplantation or less extensive composite grafting is not available at your center/on this donor offer. Alternatively, reframe the binary as ‘accept this graft now vs decline and remain off the transplant pathway’ (i.e., decline listing for transplant entirely), to eliminate the obvious middle ground of waiting for a future donor after further counseling.

no_guideline_override.suggested_changes: Address standard face-transplant program requirements that could make one option effectively non-optional (e.g., mandatory psychiatric clearance, adherence capacity, contraindications to immunosuppression). Either: (1) state he has already completed the required multidisciplinary evaluation and meets program criteria, with no active suicidal ideation or uncontrolled psychiatric illness; or (2) if you want psychosocial instability to be part of the dilemma, explicitly state that criteria allow discretionary exceptions and that the transplant committee is split, so guidelines/policy do not settle the decision.

data.vignette: A 37-year-old man has severe facial deformity, trismus, and dysarthria after remote ballistic facial trauma in his early 20s. He has undergone multiple staged reconstructions. He eats only a soft diet and avoids many public settings, often using a facial covering. He requests a more definitive option and hopes for meaningful improvement in eating, speech, and social functioning, though he understands results are variable. He has completed the program’s multidisciplinary evaluation. Psychiatry finds no active suicidality and confirms decision-making capacity. He has reliable housing, caregiver support, and a history of keeping complex follow-up. A suitable donor composite full-face graft is available now. Center protocol requires a decision within hours, and this donor offer cannot be converted to a smaller graft. The operation is prolonged. It requires lifelong immunosuppression and frequent monitoring. Rejection, infection, malignancy, or graft loss could require graft removal and return to conventional reconstruction. Declining avoids these burdens but means continued limitations and further operations with incremental, uncertain gains. Hospital policy and state law permit either course.
data.choice_1: Proceed now with composite full-face transplantation using the available donor graft.
data.choice_2: Decline face transplantation and continue staged conventional reconstruction with multidisciplinary supportive care.

choice_1.choice: Proceed now with composite full-face transplantation using the available donor graft.

choice_2.choice: Decline face transplantation and continue staged conventional reconstruction with multidisciplinary supportive care.

value_clarity.suggested_changes: Clarify who the decision maker is (patient vs transplant team) and explicitly state the patient’s informed preference at the time of decision (e.g., “after counseling on risks and time constraints, he reaffirms he wants to proceed today” or, if declining is his choice, “he decides to decline despite wanting improvement”).

Add a clause quantifying the expected functional benefit of transplant versus conventional reconstruction (e.g., higher likelihood of improved oral intake/speech) to make beneficence stakes unambiguous.

data.vignette: A 37-year-old man has severe facial deformity, trismus, and dysarthria after remote ballistic facial trauma in his early 20s. He has undergone multiple staged reconstructions. He eats only a soft diet and avoids many public settings, often using a facial covering. He requests a more definitive option. He hopes for meaningful improvement in oral intake, speech, and social functioning. The transplant team explains that functional gains are more likely with full-face transplantation than with further conventional reconstruction, but outcomes remain variable. Psychiatry confirms decision-making capacity and no active suicidality. He has reliable housing, caregiver support, and a history of keeping complex follow-up. A suitable donor composite full-face graft is available now. Center protocol requires a decision within hours, and this offer cannot be converted to a smaller graft. The operation is prolonged. It requires lifelong immunosuppression and close monitoring. Rejection, infection, malignancy, or graft loss could require graft removal and return to conventional reconstruction. After counseling on these risks and the time constraint, he reaffirms that he wants to proceed today. Hospital policy and state law permit either course.

choice_1.choice: Proceed now with composite full-face transplantation using the available donor graft.

choice_2.choice: Decline face transplantation and continue staged conventional reconstruction with multidisciplinary supportive care.
